Award.AwardTitle: FLINT: ONE CITY - ONE HUNDRED YEARS UNDER VARIABILITY
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed conference titled "Flint: One City - One Hundred Years Under Variability" is scheduled to be held at Kettering University, Flint, Michigan, June 24-28, 2014. One of the main goals of the project is to bring together experts in the fields of predictive statistics with expertise in statistical modeling, education, and applications. A specific emphasis is on statistics of historical data. Through this event, the organizers intend to celebrate the International Year of Statistics and the 175th anniversary of the American Statistical Association.

The practitioners in engineering and applied sciences are now extensively using statistical methods to solve problems arising in real-life situations dealing with local and federal governments, medical services, insurance, actuaries and public media. While most theoretical aspects and the range of applications of statistical methods have been well established, the organizers of this conference plan to bring together the most active and best researchers, educators, and practitioners to a common setting. The organizers hope that the participants such as students, teachers, and practicing statisticians will take back their experience to enhance their careers as well as to promote the use of statistics in day-to-day activities to benefit society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flint International Statistical Conference (FISC) was held at Kettering University in Flint, Michigan, in June 24 – June 28, 20114. The Title of the conference “Flint, One City - One Hundred Years Under Variability” was selected to indicate that this conference was on statistical methods and studies of historical data about the city of Flint and urban communities in general.

More than 40 participants gathered at FISC. There were researchers from Barbados, Bulgaria, Canada, Cyprus, France, Georgia, Germany, Italy, Moldavia, South Africa, Sweden, Spain, United Kingdom, and USA.

Researchers presented their work on a variety of topics, ranging from using data for urban planning, distribution of income, analysis of crime data and crime prevention, to computational methods in data extraction and analysis. Several participants discussed technical results in statistics and probability.

There was also a special guest who prepared a historical study on the presence of statistics in almost all branches of science and an invited speaker who presented his vision for teaching universityt level statistical courses with extensive use of data.

Selected presentations will appear in the Journal of Economic Quality Control published by De Gruyter and in Serdica Journal of Computing, published be the Institute of Mathematics and Informatics of the Bulgarian Academy of Sciences.
